data.text:
It is with regret that we see the UK leave the EU on 31 January. However, we welcome the ratification of the agreement for an orderly withdrawal. We have taken steps to prepare and will continue to closely monitor financial market developments. #Brexit 
https://t.co/GvayaOSdED

The approximately 2,400 less significant institutions are a substantial component of the euro area financial sector. Our comprehensive analysis of these banks examined their main risks and vulnerabilities and developments in digital-only banking. Report: https://t.co/kysMUaROsV https://t.co/y7UQCrsu0U
Working paper: Strategic interactions and price dynamics in the global oil market https://t.co/aNkW1WvsaI

Andrea Enria: The European banking market must become a truly single market. To facilitate this ECB Banking Supervision is considering concrete measures related to cross-border liquidity waivers, branching and group support for recovery plans. https://t.co/xGlNyes8TG

Are you interested in the future of Europe? Would you like to share your views with policymakers? Join us at the European Youth Event organised by @Europarl_EYE in Strasbourg. We’re hosting a workshop on new payment technologies. Register by 29/02 at https://t.co/PgJTfmGz2z https://t.co/EusGaUSdmi
The annual growth rate of broad money (M3) in the euro area decreased to 5.0% in December 2019 from 5.6% in November. Full press release https://t.co/ouaY9KOEbt https://t.co/GYRVzqf2Rk
Press release: ECB appoints Roland Straub as Counsellor to the President https://t.co/nJ0r2tUrOl
Watch again: Andrea Enria on banks’ cost of capital https://t.co/oaswl7snIm
Watch again: Andrea Enria on banks reducing NPLs https://t.co/pc0pcXARWi
Watch again: Andrea Enria on consolidation strategies https://t.co/URjQSIjQjc
Watch again: Andrea Enria on the difficulties of fit and proper assessments https://t.co/zkdW7ErfbB
Euro area economic and financial developments by institutional sector (Q3 2019) https://t.co/GXPciSm1bF

Andrea Enria: We are making progress with the post-crisis cleaning of banks’ balance sheets. In 2014, non-performing loans (NPLs) represented 8% of all loans in the euro area. Since then, the NPL ratio has fallen to 3.4%.

Andrea Enria: Banks’ resilience and the sustainability of their business models remain our top priorities. We may step up supervisory pressure if the banks’ self-help measures are not effective enough.
Andrea Enria: Banks must sharpen their managerial efforts to refocus their business models, deploy effective digitalisation strategies and more radically improve their cost efficiency.

Andrea Enria: A prominent area of concern is the low profitability of European banks. Many of them do not earn their costs of capital and valuations remain low. This means low organic generation of capital and lower ability to raise equity under challenging economic conditions.

Andrea Enria: Qualitative measures aim to address severe weaknesses in the internal control functions of banks, ineffective management bodies and deficient risk management. In short, we are concerned about governance.

Andrea Enria: A breakdown of qualitative measures shows that supervisory concerns focus on internal governance: almost a third of all remedial actions relate to the governance of banks https://t.co/OE5Y5wYP1x
Andrea Enria: Almost all banks have adequate levels of capital above all requirements, including the systemic and countercyclical buffers https://t.co/OE5Y5wYP1x

Andrea Enria: Looking at business models, global systemically important banks face comparable capital requirements and lower Pillar 2 guidance, reflecting higher resilience in stress test exercises https://t.co/OE5Y5wYP1x

Andrea Enria: Individual outcomes vary, reflecting changes in the underlying risk profile. Overall capital requirements and guidance changed for one in every three banks, going up in about 15% of cases and down in another 15% https://t.co/OE5Y5wYP1x

Andrea Enria: Common Equity Tier 1 (CET1) capital requirements and guidance remain stable at 10.6%. This confirms a stabilisation in the supervisory assessment on banks’ capital needs https://t.co/OE5Y5wYP1x

For the first time ever we are publishing individual Pillar 2 requirements (P2R), says Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria. 108 banks in this SREP (Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process) cycle consented to have their P2R published on our website https://t.co/OE5Y5wYP1x https://t.co/R2ZlZ4AP5y
Tune in now to watch the ECB Banking Supervision press conference https://t.co/flZrDqJsMY https://t.co/GwD2Va6oRg

The annual review highlighted the concerns facing banks, in particular in relation to business models, internal governance and operational risks. These are the areas in which the ECB will sharpen the focus of its supervisory work. https://t.co/7gqYzyq4nv https://t.co/18UjiHUsLB

The results of the 2019 SREP are in: Banks’ overall capital requirements remain unchanged at 10.6% and banks are broadly meeting targets for reducing NPL volumes. However, internal governance shows signs of deterioration and low profitability remains a key concern. https://t.co/LFwoozAJxF

The 2019 Supervisory Review and Evaluation Process results are now available. But what is the SREP? Check out our animation and find out more in the new pages on our website https://t.co/RZxjqbOFp7 https://t.co/w4RZWq24Eo

We’ve published more granular results and further details on the SREP methodology for the first time, as well as a list of banks’ Pillar 2 Requirements. The results are available in a new dedicated section on our website https://t.co/RZxjqbOFp7 https://t.co/oYi4huLZqS

Today, President @Lagarde, Prof. Dr. @MirjamWenzel, Director of the Jewish Museum in Frankfurt, and Uwe Becker, Mayor of the City of Frankfurt, placed a candle and observed a minute of silence at the Jewish Memorial on the ECB’s premises in honour of the victims of the Holocaust. https://t.co/1qR0GDorlF

The memorial marks the place from which more than 10,000 members of Frankfurt’s Jewish population were deported to concentration camps between 1941 and 1945. 

More about the Jewish memorial on the ECB’s premises: https://t.co/dKK5jpLlU2

#holocaust-remembrance-day #WeRemember
Speech Yves Mersch: Asset price inflation and monetary policy https://t.co/tsi8hKqOMR

Why do we care about banks being profitable? Profitability is an indicator of the health of a bank, ECB supervisor Linette Field explains to our host @michaelsteen in the latest episode of The ECB #Podcast. Tune in for more https://t.co/mDaAjXp1yP https://t.co/e966Ei6Nkb
Decisions taken by the Governing Council of the ECB (in addition to decisions setting interest rates) https://t.co/SqSM3B6mmd

Are you conducting research on a topic related to inflation? You have until 14 February to submit your paper for the Inflation: drivers and dynamics 2020 conference taking place in Cleveland, USA, on 21-22 May. More details and how to apply https://t.co/LlEhZ7JpNq https://t.co/ORKYfrFjJE
Letter from the ECB President to Ms Eva Kaili, MEP, on payment services https://t.co/1AmfJ92TKq (EN) https://t.co/HPuWGxBLTy (EL)
Letter from the ECB President to Mr Giorgos Georgiou, MEP, on access to cash https://t.co/p1UZEXtF4N

Letter from the ECB President to Mr Marco Zanni, Ms Francesca Donato, Mr Valentino Grant and Mr Antonio Maria Rinaldi, MEPs, on monetary policy https://t.co/796HW4RnbA (EN) https://t.co/kQQ2oUM2pH (IT)
Working paper: Lifting the banking veil: credit standards’ harmonization through lending transparency https://t.co/xLYrgClpgf
Press release: Euro banknote counterfeiting remained low in the second half of 2019 https://t.co/AycWGyO8NI
Press release: Results of the Q1 2020 ECB Survey of Professional Forecasters https://t.co/OmthsoTzUW
Coming up today: President Christine @Lagarde discusses the global economic outlook at the World Economic Forum #WEF20. Follow live here from 11:30 CET https://t.co/CweUJ3gHpP https://t.co/qAwcMbGluq
Speech Christine Lagarde: How can a united Europe meet the challenges it faces today? https://t.co/NvOEIjz8ec
Watch again: Lagarde on price stability in a changing environment https://t.co/mN5KZIwwGx
Watch again: Lagarde on the role of central banks in the fight against climate change https://t.co/jikV5DUHPX
Watch again: Lagarde on how listening to people’s concerns will form part of the monetary policy strategy review https://t.co/y1bOHuMMCs
Speech Christine Lagarde: How can a united Europe meet the challenges it faces today? https://t.co/NvOEIjz8ec
Introductory statement to the press conference https://t.co/BwLs5BEmab
ECB launches review of its monetary policy strategy https://t.co/uh0IFBGi1s
Lagarde: We have good reasons to believe banks are well prepared for Brexit
Lagarde: I'm not a despotic president. All views are welcome. But at the end of the day and at the end of the process, we still have to release a monetary policy decision.
Lagarde: Two of the countries that have fiscal space are now seriously looking at how to expand more fiscally with their respective budgets. So there is progress.
Lagarde: At euro area level, there is a very mild fiscal expansion as we speak

Lagarde: We cannot operate as we did back in 2003, which doesn't mean to say that we have to change this, that and the other, but we have to look comprehensively at the effectiveness of our monetary policy
Lagarde: Climate change is a threat that his hardly measured and taken into account by actors
Lagarde: We are going to look at the potential side effects of low rates as part of our strategy review
Lagarde: I'm concerned about low rates, because they are predicated on low growth. I would much rather have much higher growth, higher rates. But this is not the situation we have at the moment.
Introductory statement Christine Lagarde to the press conference https://t.co/BwLs5BEmab
Lagarde: Environment and sustainability is very prominent in our strategy review
Lagarde: There is work ongoing in various departments at the ECB that climate change is embedded in terms of risk assessment, models, forecasts, this is work in progress
Lagarde: Small rivers make large oceans - when they are well protected
Lagarde: Climate change is everybody's responsibility, where ever he or she is to fight climate change and risks to biodiversity
Lagarde: The tiering system has proven to be effective, no questions about it
Lagarde: We will listen to expectations of the people to better understand their concerns
Lagarde: The review will have to do with how we deliver, how we measure, how we communicate when it comes to decision making, publication, outreach
Lagarde: We are going to review a whole host of issues
Lagarde: The role of the ECB and the Eurosystem at large is to deliver on price stability and one of the avenues to deliver is to make sure that there is growth in our economies
Lagarde: The trade agreement between US and China has slightly reduced uncertainty but impact on net basis for the euro area needs to be assessed
Lagarde: Trade is actually an important element in our considerations and in assessing the downside risks
Lagarde: In countries where public debt is high, governments need to pursue prudent policies and meet structural balance targets
Lagarde: Governments with fiscal space should be ready to act in an effective and timely manner
Lagarde: The Governing Council welcomes the Eurogroup’s call in December for differentiated fiscal responses and its readiness to coordinate

Lagarde: The implementation of structural policies in euro area countries needs to be substantially stepped up to boost euro area productivity and growth potential, reduce structural unemployment and increase resilience

Lagarde: In order to reap the full benefits from our monetary policy measures, other policy areas must contribute more decisively to raising the longer-term growth potential, supporting aggregate demand at the current juncture and reducing vulnerabilities
Lagarde: An ample degree of monetary accommodation is still necessary for the continued robust convergence of inflation to levels that are below, but close to, 2% over the medium term

Lagarde: The growth of loans to firms and households remained solid, benefiting from the ongoing support provided by our accommodative monetary policy stance which is reflected in very low bank lending rates
Lagarde: …but risks have become less pronounced as some of the uncertainty surrounding international trade is receding (2/2)
Lagarde: The risks surrounding the euro area growth outlook, related to geopolitical factors, rising protectionism and vulnerabilities in emerging markets, remain tilted to the downside …(1/2)

Lagarde: The Governing Council stands ready to adjust all of its instruments, as appropriate, to ensure that inflation moves towards its aim in a sustained manner, in line with its commitment to symmetry
Lagarde: Our forward guidance will ensure that financial conditions adjust in accordance with changes to the inflation outlook
Lagarde: We will closely monitor inflation developments and the impact of the unfolding monetary policy measures on the economy

Lagarde: In the light of the continued subdued inflation outlook, monetary policy has to remain highly accommodative for a prolonged period of time to support underlying inflation pressures and headline inflation developments over the medium term
Lagarde: Easier borrowing conditions will sustain the euro area expansion, the build-up of domestic price pressures and, thus, the robust convergence of inflation to our medium-term aim
Lagarde: In particular, easier borrowing conditions for firms and households are supporting consumer spending and business investment
Lagarde: The unfolding monetary policy measures are underpinning favourable financing conditions for all sectors of the economy
Lagarde: While inflation developments remain subdued overall, there are some signs of a moderate increase in underlying inflation in line with expectations
Lagarde: Ongoing, albeit decelerating, employment growth and increasing wages continue to support the resilience of the euro area economy
Lagarde: The Governing Council decided to launch a review of the ECB’s monetary policy strategy

Lagarde: We intend to continue reinvesting, in full, the principal payments from maturing securities purchased under the APP for an extended period of time past the date when we start raising the key ECB interest rates
Lagarde: We expect net purchases to run for as long as necessary to reinforce the accommodative impact of our policy rates, and to end shortly before we start raising the key ECB interest rates
Lagarde: ... and until convergence has been consistently reflected in underlying inflation dynamics (2/2)

Lagarde: We expect ECB interest rates to remain at their present or lower levels until we have seen the inflation outlook robustly converge to a level sufficiently close to, but below, 2% within our projection horizon…(1/2)
Watch the ECB press conference live: President Christine Lagarde explains today’s monetary policy decisions https://t.co/JyeWtjV19u
Coming up in 15 minutes: ECB President Christine Lagarde explains today’s monetary policy decisions. https://t.co/WBrbGINIem
We also release our monetary policy decisions via a system called Market Information Dissemination (MID) https://t.co/UgQkULHFw6 and by reading them out to media.

Due to a temporary technical issue, we were late issuing the press release on monetary policy decisions on our website. The announcement went out on time to the media and markets via our other systems. 

The press release is now here: https://t.co/0RBOnWEjTD
Later today: watch live as ECB President Christine Lagarde explains today’s monetary policy decisions. https://t.co/yOXZbLEIVA

We are looking for trainees! Want to be at the heart of action in Europe? Curious about how we manage the euro – one of the world’s most important currencies – and make sure money is safe in banks? Then what are you waiting for? Apply now https://t.co/He1i70e5dh
#ECBtrainee #ecb https://t.co/UGFBpLwFUM

Why should banks be able to fail? Our host @MichaelSteen discusses this and other questions with Supervisory Board Chair Andrea Enria in the latest episode of The ECB #Podcast https://t.co/RqiyRyQqke https://t.co/rC4PNv4y4V

Have banks become safer since the financial crisis? Who pays when a bank goes bust? @MichaelSteen discusses these and other questions with Andrea Enria, Pien van Erp Taalman Kip and Linette Field in the latest episode of The ECB #Podcast. Listen here https://t.co/RqiyRyQqke https://t.co/wggj2Sshgj
Central bank group to assess potential cases for central bank digital currencies https://t.co/XA5w0ovzAs
